description: This is an inbuilt weighing system for construction machines like dumpers and excavators, to weigh the material directly during loading. It works dynamically, without the machine must stop. It uses an angle sensor, bucket switch, acceleration sensor and hydraulic pressure sensors to calculate the weight. Bern, Switzerland, March 20, 2014.

description:
Yay. Because ... after posting an image I'm rather happy with, like the last one, I find it pretty hard to post again because I hold myself to the standard I've set. Dangerous precedent and all. And also yay because this happens to be a street shot I'm happy with again - I still have trouble finding proper stories there and then also having the guts to photograph them.

This is an image from a little photowalk; we have these irregularly and today we nearly cancelled because of the bad weather, but went to a lokal park anyway.

description:
Explored 16MAR2016

This is a segment in the original dimension of the "Gotthard Base Tunnel" and measures 9.5 meters in diameter.
This is a temporary exhibition, right now taking place in Bern.
The railway-tunnel in the Swiss Alps will open this year and with its 57km will be the longest and deepest traffic-tunnel of the world!

I have chosen the long exposure to "erase" people walking around but also to blur the sky, so that the clouds don't distract form the subject(s).

description:
WWPW Bern

Bern Bundesplatz has the greatest guys playing chess on the public chessboard. One can only guess what of amazing amount of life and experiences meet here. The place has this kind of magical radiation you can't quite grasp but clearly feel. I love places and people like these!

*******************************************************************************************
You can also follow me on Twitter.com/fredmancosu or on Facebook.com/mancosu

description:
I figured I'd go and see whether the milky way is visible from the Bantiger hill, right next to this radio tower. Turns out it was, but when I arrived and prepared for the shoot, I realized that the widest lens I had brought with me was by no means a wide angle. So I compromised and shot this subject here again. You haven't seen any pictures of it yet, even though I've shot a few from this very spot here, but I never was as happy as I am with this version now.

After the photograph, I stayed for about half an hour longer and just stared into the sky, watching the stars. It's been a while since I last did that. It's humbling.
tags: omd em1 olympus sky stars radio tower bantiger bern switzerland bolligen ostermundigen schweiz

description:
Een portofoon, ook wel walkie-talkie genoemd, is een draagbaar zend-ontvangtoestel voor communicatie tussen meerdere personen. De benaming portofoon wordt voornamelijk gebruikt bij professionele gebruikers zoals hulpdiensten. De benaming walkie-talkie wordt meestal gebruikt bij apparaten voor recreatief gebruik zoals speelgoed. Deze benaming is ontstaan doordat men, in tegenstelling tot bij een vaste telefoon, tijdens het gesprek (talk) kan lopen (walk).
Met een portofoon kan geluisterd worden naar de andere gebruikers die op dezelfde frequentie luisteren. Daarnaast kan één persoon tegelijk praten, door middel van het indrukken van een knop. Op het moment dat de knop is ingedrukt is het niet mogelijk naar de andere gebruikers te luisteren, de andere gebruikers kunnen dan overigens ook niet zenden. Dit principe wordt half-duplex genoemd.
tags: ek2008 cinevideogroup motorola porto radio euro2008 ekvoetbal gp340

description: 17º dia de viagem - Berna, Suíça. Berna (Suíço-alemão Bärn, alemão Bern, francês Berne, italiano Berna, romanche Berna) é a capital da Suíça. Berna é uma cidade germanófona, capital do cantão homônimo e também uma comuna. Berna conta com aproximadamente 127 217 habitantes, incluindo-se a aglomeração. Estende-se por uma área de 51,6 km², de densidade populacional de 2465 hab/km² e é atravessada pelo rio Aar, confinando com as seguintes comunas: Bremgarten bei Bern, Frauenkappelen, Ittigen, Kirchlindach, Köniz, Mühleberg, Muri bei Bern, Neuenegg, Ostermundigen, Wohlen bei Bern, Zollikofen. Berna está inscrita no Patrimônio Cultural Mundial da UNESCO, graças ao seu patrimônio medieval urbano, que conseguiu atravessar os séculos. Entre os bernenses ilustres encontram-se o cientista Albrecht von Haller, o poeta Jeremias Gotthelf, o escultor Bernhard Luginbühl e os pintores Ferdinand Hodler e Paul Klee. O físico de origem alemã Albert Einstein desenvolveu sua Teoria da Relatividade em Berna. A língua oficial nesta comuna é o Alemão. História Berna foi fundada em 1191 pelo duque Berthold V de Zähringen que, de acordo com a lenda, teria dado o nome a cidade após ter matado um urso (Bär em alemão) — existiram ursos em Berna durante séculos. Pode-se ainda hoje vê-los na fossa dos ursos perto da Nydeggbrücke. Em 1353, Berna tornou-se o oitavo cantão da então jovem Confederação Suíça. Após um incêndio em 1405, a cidade foi inteiramente reconstruída. Em 1848, a nova constituição federal faz de Berna a capital da Suíça. Wikipédia 17th day of journey - Berne, Switzerland Berne's city center is largely medieval and has been recognised by UNESCO as a Cultural World Heritage Site. Perhaps its most famous sight is the Zytglogge, an elaborate medieval clock tower with moving puppets. It also has an impressive 15th century Gothic cathedral, the Münster, and a 15th century town hall. Thanks to 6 kilometers of arcades, the old town boasts one of the longest covered shopping promenades in Europe. Since the 16th century, the city has had a bear pit (the Bärengraben), which can be visited off the far end of the Nydeggbrücke. The Federal Palace (Bundeshaus), dating from 1902, which houses the national parliament and part of the federal administration, can also be visited. Einstein lived in an apartment at the Kramgasse 49, the site of the Einsteinhaus, from 1903 to 1905, the year in which the Annus Mirabilis Papers were published. The Garden of Roses (Rosengarten), from where a scenic panorama view of the medieval city core can be enjoyed, is a well-kept Rosary on a hill, converted into a park from a former cemetery in 1913. Wikipedia

description: Philippe services the bottom bracket in his hobby shop with the proper tool for every step.  This man knows his craft as he renovates another M05 for a friend.  I had the pleasure of borrowing this fahrrad for the afternoon.  Robust-smooth is perhaps the best way to describe the fine ride.  While a hog uphill, the ride quality on the flats is a real joy to know. (info@ordonnanzrad.ch)

description:
December 2011


I look to the hills! Where will I find help?
It will come from the Lord,  who created the heavens and the earth.
The Lord is your protector, and he won't go to sleep or let you stumble.
The protector of Israel doesn't doze or ever get drowsy.
The Lord is your protector, there at your right side to shade you from the sun.
You won't be harmed by the sun during the day or by the moon at night. 
The Lord will protect you and keep you safe from all dangers.
The Lord will protect you now and always wherever you go.

Psalm 121

description:
WWPW Bern

Bern Bundesplatz has the greatest guys playing chess on the public chessboard. One can only guess what of amazing amount of life and experiences meet here. The place has this kind of magical radiation you can't quite grasp but clearly feel. I love places and people like these!

description: This is the first image I explicitly made for one of the assignments of the 115 pictures in 2015 Flickr group. One of the assignments is "The Number 7". I figured a keyboard's 7 key would do. Quite a few times, I played around with DOF while watching Netflix, and never got anything I really liked. This approach of a longer exposure time and camera movement during the exposure worked better for me. Today was a very busy day and I didn't have time to shoot during the day. I knew that in advance though and made this photograph shortly after midnight last night ;) #007/115 ("The Number 7") for the 115 pictures in 2015 challenge.
tags: number 7 mac apple seven keyboard 115in2015 project365 computer technology blur motion

description: ...and now for something completely different. Yeah, I guess I haven't really found "my style" yet, considering the extreme contrast between the rather subtle tones of yesterday's B/W conversion on one hand, and this screaming HDR rendering on the other 0:-) In my defense, I met my friend Michel Varrin yesterday, who loves HDR, and I guess he inspired me to do some HDR-ing of my own again for a change :) Made with Photomatix Pro from five exposures at 7mm (14mm eq.), f/5.6, ISO 200, with -4/-2/0/+2/+4 EV.

description:
Photo André Knoerr, Genève. Reproduction autorisée avec mention de la source.
Utilisation commerciale soumise à autorisation préalable.

La locomotive historique BLS EZB Ce 4/6 307 "Dekretsmühle" démarre de Schwarzenburg avec quatre voitures à plateformes ouvertes, lors de circulations spéciales pour un jubilé de la ligne Bern - Schwarzenburg du GBS.
Il existe actuellement un avant projet de mise à voie métrique de cette ligne pour créer une diamétrale S-Bahn Solothurn - Bern - (nouveau tronçon souterrain sous la ville) - Schwarzenburg.

description:
Photo André Knoerr, Genève. Reproduction autorisée avec mention de la source.
Utilisation commerciale soumise à autorisation préalable.

La composition RBDe 566' RBDe 4/4 261 + B 507 + Bt 361 assure un régional en direction de Burgdorf.
La motrice VHB 261 prendra le numéro 566 220 au RM et au BLS.
Les RBDe 566' ont cessé tout service commercial régulier en décembre 2014.
La 566 222 est cependant en réserve aux CJ sur la ligne Porrentruy - Bonfol.

seit der platz direkt vor dem berner bundeshaus (schweizer parlaments- und regierungssitz) nicht mehr einfach ein parkplatz ist, sondern von den stadtberner behörden zu einem veritablen öffentlichen raum mit springbrunnen umgestaltet wurde, hat sich die bevölkerung den bundesplatz zurückerobert. allen voran die kinder.

since the place directly in front of the bernese bundeshaus (house of parliament and seat of the swiss government) was no longer just a simple parking lot, but has been transformed by the local authorities to a veritable public area with jumping wells, it has been back-captured by the inhabitants. especially by the children.

description:
View on the scenic old town of Bern and the Bern Cathedral (UNESCO World Cultural Heritage).

Taken with my iPhone 4 before a severe thunder and hail storm approached. 
Unfortunately, I didn't have my camera gear with me.

The city of Bern or Berne is the Bundesstadt (federal city, de facto capital) of Switzerland, and, with (as of December 2009) a population of 131,000, the fourth most populous city in Switzerland. The Bern agglomeration, which includes 43 municipalities, has a population of 349,000. The metropolitan area had a population of 660,000 in 2000. Bern is also the capital of the Canton of Bern, the second most populous of Switzerland's cantons.

The official language of Bern is German, but the main spoken language is the Alemannic dialect called Bernese German.

In 1983 the historic old town in the center of Bern became a UNESCO World Heritage Sites, and Bern is ranked among the world’s top ten cities for the best quality of life.

The etymology of the name Bern is uncertain. According to the local legend, based on folk etymology, Berchtold V, Duke of Zähringen, the founder of the city of Bern, vowed to name the city after the first animal he met on the hunt, and this turned out to be a bear. It has long been considered likely that the city was named after the Italian city of Verona, which at the time was known as Bern in Middle High German. As a result of the find of the Berne zinc tablet in the 1980, it is now more common to assume that the city was named after a pre-existing toponym of celtic origin, possibly *berna "cleft". The bear was the heraldic animal of the seal and coat of arms of Bern from at least the 1220s. The earliest reference to the keeping of live bears in the Bärengraben dates to the 1440s.

The structure of Bern's city center is largely medieval and has been recognised by UNESCO as a Cultural World Heritage Site. Perhaps its most famous sight is the Zytglogge (Bernese German for "Time Bell"), an elaborate medieval clock tower with moving puppets. It also has an impressive 15th century Gothic cathedral, the Münster, and a 15th century town hall. Thanks to 6 kilometers of arcades, the old town boasts one of the longest covered shopping promenades in Europe (Lauben).

Since the 16th century, the city has had a bear pit (the Bärengraben). The extended and renewed pit off the far end of the Nydeggbrücke actually contains four bears, including two young. During his visit in Bern in 2009, the Russian president and his wife gave two more young bears as a private present. They are actually in Dählhölzli, Bern's zoo.

The Federal Palace (Bundeshaus), built from 1857 to 1902, which houses the national parliament, government and part of the federal administration, can also be visited.

Albert Einstein lived in an apartment at the Kramgasse 49, the site of the Einsteinhaus, from 1903 to 1905, the year in which the Annus Mirabilis Papers were published.

The Garden of Roses (Rosengarten), from which a scenic panoramic view of the medieval town centre can be enjoyed, is a well-kept Rosary on a hill, converted into a park from a former cemetery in 1913.

Bern's most recent sight is the set of fountains in front of the Federal Palace. It was inaugurated on August 1, 2004.

Bern features many heritage sites of national significance. Apart from the entire Old Town and many sites within it, these include the Bärengraben, the Gewerbeschule Bern (1937), the Eidgenössisches Archiv für Denkmalpflege, the Kirchenfeld mansion district (after 1881), the Thunplatzbrunnen, the Federal Mint building, the Federal Archives, the Swiss National Library, the Historical Museum (1894), Alpine Museum, Museum of Communication and Natural History Museum.
The Universal Postal Union is situated in Bern.
[Source: Wikipedia]

iPhone 4
Processed with PS CS5

During his visit in Bern in 2009, the Russian president and his wife gave two more young bears as a private present. They are actually in Dählhölzli, Bern's zoo.

The Federal Palace (Bundeshaus), built from 1857 to 1902, which houses the national parliament, government and part of the federal administration, can also be visited.

Albert Einstein lived in an apartment at the Kramgasse 49, the site of the Einsteinhaus, from 1903 to 1905, the year in which the Annus Mirabilis Papers were published.

The Garden of Roses (Rosengarten), from which a scenic panoramic view of the medieval town centre can be enjoyed, is a well-kept Rosary on a hill, converted into a park from a former cemetery in 1913.

Bern's most recent sight is the set of fountains in front of the Federal Palace. It was inaugurated on August 1, 2004.

Bern features many heritage sites of national significance. Apart from the entire Old Town and many sites within it, these include the Bärengraben, the Gewerbeschule Bern (1937), the Eidgenössisches Archiv für Denkmalpflege, the Kirchenfeld mansion district (after 1881), the Thunplatzbrunnen, the Federal Mint building, the Federal Archives, the Swiss National Library, the Historical Museum (1894), Alpine Museum, Museum of Communication and Natural History Museum.
The Universal Postal Union is situated in Bern.

description:
View on the scenic old town of Bern and the Bern Cathedral (UNESCO World Cultural Heritage).

Taken with my iPhone 4 before a severe thunder and hail storm approached. 
Unfortunately, I didn't have my camera gear with me.

The city of Bern or Berne is the Bundesstadt (federal city, de facto capital) of Switzerland, and, with (as of December 2009) a population of 131,000, the fourth most populous city in Switzerland. The Bern agglomeration, which includes 43 municipalities, has a population of 349,000. The metropolitan area had a population of 660,000 in 2000. Bern is also the capital of the Canton of Bern, the second most populous of Switzerland's cantons.

The official language of Bern is German, but the main spoken language is the Alemannic dialect called Bernese German.

In 1983 the historic old town in the center of Bern became a UNESCO World Heritage Sites, and Bern is ranked among the world’s top ten cities for the best quality of life.

The etymology of the name Bern is uncertain. According to the local legend, based on folk etymology, Berchtold V, Duke of Zähringen, the founder of the city of Bern, vowed to name the city after the first animal he met on the hunt, and this turned out to be a bear. It has long been considered likely that the city was named after the Italian city of Verona, which at the time was known as Bern in Middle High German. As a result of the find of the Berne zinc tablet in the 1980, it is now more common to assume that the city was named after a pre-existing toponym of celtic origin, possibly *berna "cleft". The bear was the heraldic animal of the seal and coat of arms of Bern from at least the 1220s. The earliest reference to the keeping of live bears in the Bärengraben dates to the 1440s.

The structure of Bern's city center is largely medieval and has been recognised by UNESCO as a Cultural World Heritage Site. Perhaps its most famous sight is the Zytglogge (Bernese German for "Time Bell"), an elaborate medieval clock tower with moving puppets. It also has an impressive 15th century Gothic cathedral, the Münster, and a 15th century town hall. Thanks to 6 kilometers of arcades, the old town boasts one of the longest covered shopping promenades in Europe (Lauben).

Since the 16th century, the city has had a bear pit (the Bärengraben). The extended and renewed pit off the far end of the Nydeggbrücke actually contains four bears, including two young. During his visit in Bern in 2009, the Russian president and his wife gave two more young bears as a private present. They are actually in Dählhölzli, Bern's zoo.

The Federal Palace (Bundeshaus), built from 1857 to 1902, which houses the national parliament, government and part of the federal administration, can also be visited.

Albert Einstein lived in an apartment at the Kramgasse 49, the site of the Einsteinhaus, from 1903 to 1905, the year in which the Annus Mirabilis Papers were published.

The Garden of Roses (Rosengarten), from which a scenic panoramic view of the medieval town centre can be enjoyed, is a well-kept Rosary on a hill, converted into a park from a former cemetery in 1913.

Bern's most recent sight is the set of fountains in front of the Federal Palace. It was inaugurated on August 1, 2004.

Bern features many heritage sites of national significance. Apart from the entire Old Town and many sites within it, these include the Bärengraben, the Gewerbeschule Bern (1937), the Eidgenössisches Archiv für Denkmalpflege, the Kirchenfeld mansion district (after 1881), the Thunplatzbrunnen, the Federal Mint building, the Federal Archives, the Swiss National Library, the Historical Museum (1894), Alpine Museum, Museum of Communication and Natural History Museum.
The Universal Postal Union is situated in Bern.
[Source: Wikipedia]

description: Frozen in Bern, Switzerland on 1989-11-29. After seeing Rome I caught the train to Florence and checked into the Youth Hostel. There I met a great guy called Serge Bowers (from Allentown, Pennsylvania, USA), Brian Bennett (from Sydney, Australia) and four trainee nurses (from Stockport, Manchester, Cheshire, UK) - Diane Peterson, Michelle Syddall, Karen Goldrick and Miranda Parr. Between November 18-20. 1989 we had a wonderful time visiting the sights of Florence and Pisa...and drank way too much cheap wine! Serge then headed for Amsterdam while the nurses and I headed for Venice. November 21-24 was an exceptionally wet and cold patch in Venice, exacerbated by the Youth Hostal's draconian day time lock-out policy. I then parted way from the nurses and headed to Milan and Arese, where I visited the Museo Alfa Romeo. Eerie experience - they opened up and switched on the lights for me, and I was the only person there for the whole day! I was in Milan from November 25-27 and then caught the train to Lausanne in Switzerland, where I spend the day on November 28. Too expensive...I decided to get out of the country as soon as possible! On November 29, I spent the day in Bern, where it was bloody freezing. Who knows where I was walking when I took this shot - I guess I was trying to get the iconic view of the Old City? It must be a selfie, as I'm not carrying my camera bag. I clearly found something to put it on, propped up my Pentax ME Super on the bag and set the mechanical timer. I'm on a street called Aargauerstalden with the Aare River in the valley below me. That's the Bern Minster (Cathedral) to my left and the Kornhausbrücke to my right. 35mm Pentax ME Super with an SMC Pentax-M 50mm f1.7 lens. Google Maps - that's about the same vantage point. 46.951302, 7.459855

description:
The last big country in western Europe left for me to see. Prettier than I expected and I think I will visit it again, well, we have the sticker to drive there for one year, so it makes sense :)

It was rainy and the light was not ideal for a quick photo, but somehow there was enough information on it to work it. I like the end result.

It's more for practicing, I really doubt this perspective is new and that its not been done 1000's of times. That tought sometimes pushes me down, whats the point of making another photo of the same spot that every tourist make? Why not just buying a postcard and look for one in internet from someone with better skills and just save the hassle? No idea, but I am afraid one day I might give in to these toughts.

What if there is a solar flare that wipes all the electronic data and all is lost? The huge collective look of humanity would be something worth taking a photo of, but the cameras wouldnt work. Should I be paranoic and have some physical backups? Maybe, and also get a tinfoil hat while I am at it.

description:
Bus/tram terminal at Bern train station. Above you see the light reflections at the glass roof (called "Baldachin").
Picture taken with a Leitz Canada Telyt 280mm f/4.8 lens from 1961 with an aperture of f/16. As you can see, it's not easy to get any starbursts, but the lens is pretty sharp in my opinion (look at a 100% crop anywhere in the frame). The mechanics of this lens is fantastic anyway, so the fun of using it starts when you touch it first :-)

description:
View on the scenic old town of Bern and the Bern Cathedral (UNESCO World Cultural Heritage).

Taken with my iPhone 4 before a severe thunder and hail storm approached. 
Unfortunately, I didn't have my camera gear with me.

The city of Bern or Berne is the Bundesstadt (federal city, de facto capital) of Switzerland, and, with (as of December 2009) a population of 131,000, the fourth most populous city in Switzerland. The Bern agglomeration, which includes 43 municipalities, has a population of 349,000. The metropolitan area had a population of 660,000 in 2000. Bern is also the capital of the Canton of Bern, the second most populous of Switzerland's cantons.

The official language of Bern is German, but the main spoken language is the Alemannic dialect called Bernese German.

In 1983 the historic old town in the center of Bern became a UNESCO World Heritage Sites, and Bern is ranked among the world’s top ten cities for the best quality of life.

The etymology of the name Bern is uncertain. According to the local legend, based on folk etymology, Berchtold V, Duke of Zähringen, the founder of the city of Bern, vowed to name the city after the first animal he met on the hunt, and this turned out to be a bear. It has long been considered likely that the city was named after the Italian city of Verona, which at the time was known as Bern in Middle High German. As a result of the find of the Berne zinc tablet in the 1980, it is now more common to assume that the city was named after a pre-existing toponym of celtic origin, possibly *berna "cleft". The bear was the heraldic animal of the seal and coat of arms of Bern from at least the 1220s. The earliest reference to the keeping of live bears in the Bärengraben dates to the 1440s.

The structure of Bern's city center is largely medieval and has been recognised by UNESCO as a Cultural World Heritage Site. Perhaps its most famous sight is the Zytglogge (Bernese German for "Time Bell"), an elaborate medieval clock tower with moving puppets. It also has an impressive 15th century Gothic cathedral, the Münster, and a 15th century town hall. Thanks to 6 kilometers of arcades, the old town boasts one of the longest covered shopping promenades in Europe (Lauben).

Since the 16th century, the city has had a bear pit (the Bärengraben). The extended and renewed pit off the far end of the Nydeggbrücke actually contains four bears, including two young. During his visit in Bern in 2009, the Russian president and his wife gave two more young bears as a private present. They are actually in Dählhölzli, Bern's zoo.

The Federal Palace (Bundeshaus), built from 1857 to 1902, which houses the national parliament, government and part of the federal administration, can also be visited.

Albert Einstein lived in an apartment at the Kramgasse 49, the site of the Einsteinhaus, from 1903 to 1905, the year in which the Annus Mirabilis Papers were published.

The Garden of Roses (Rosengarten), from which a scenic panoramic view of the medieval town centre can be enjoyed, is a well-kept Rosary on a hill, converted into a park from a former cemetery in 1913.

Bern's most recent sight is the set of fountains in front of the Federal Palace. It was inaugurated on August 1, 2004.

Bern features many heritage sites of national significance. Apart from the entire Old Town and many sites within it, these include the Bärengraben, the Gewerbeschule Bern (1937), the Eidgenössisches Archiv für Denkmalpflege, the Kirchenfeld mansion district (after 1881), the Thunplatzbrunnen, the Federal Mint building, the Federal Archives, the Swiss National Library, the Historical Museum (1894), Alpine Museum, Museum of Communication and Natural History Museum.
The Universal Postal Union is situated in Bern.
[Source: Wikipedia]

iPhone 4
Processed with PS CS5

description: This photo shows the setup for scenario 3 ("Hydrographic Survey Mission") of the Voyage of the Beagle expansion for Robinson Crusoe. I haven't actually played any of the expansion content yet, and don't know how this would work at all, but I'm told that it's very, very awesome and kind of a new game that plays similar to Robinson Crusoe... I'll play the scenarios in sequence and thus am still ahem approaching the second one of six (plus promo scenarios). I played the first scenario once and won on the first try, which was surprising yet awesome. I like my solo games challenging, and it was challenging - I nearly lost - so considering that the following scenarios are due to become harder, the balance feels great to me so far.
tags: omd em1 board games boardgames robinson crusoe darwin travels ship sea cards tokens cardboard
